componenttext: The U.S, as I mentioned earlier, we have been able to see the continued shift of large advertisers, which started in Q3 and continued into Q4 and has been reasonably strong. On the international side, I'm very pleased with the growth we've seen across the world, but you have to understand, there's a mix issue. There are different parts of the world, which have growth at different basis, unless we continue to see growth in most markets, there are some of the markets where we're seeing growths, which are like Brazil, as I mentioned, which are causing that growth rate to look different than the U.S.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Mark Mahaney from Citigroup.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: The sequential growth is actually very similar to what you had in 2007, is it pretty clear to you that overall search spending trends are kind of back to normal seasonal patterns, or are there still; verticals that seem still weak to you, not retail,  obviously, but other areas? And then secondly, the materiality of Mobile, could you talk about any data points? The sequential growth in searches, what percentage of searches are up mobile devices in any particular markets?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: In a very general issue, we won't comment on -- about the Mobile and how it affects our total revenue. And then in general, there's clearly --  I mean, you see through the second half of 2009 our recovery in economic activity worldwide, and that clearly has shown up in our results. But I'll let Nikesh give you a bit more per se.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: From a vertical perspective, as I mentioned, we have seen very strong strength in the retail vertical across the board, pretty much around the world. We've also continued to see strength in the technology vertical. As you would expect, finance was not as strong as it was in 2007, and we're seeing stabilization and some amount of recovery. And in addition to that, we continue to make progress at all the other verticals like CPG, health, local, etc.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Ben Schachter from Broadpoint AmTech.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: If you could rank the key model addition changes you made in 4Q, and how do you think they're going to impact the model going forward? And then on Mobile, I just wonder if you could have a broader discussion about how you think about the P&L there? Is this something that you want to drive revenues? Is this something, you just want to push the Internet experience forward on mobile? And then finally, any comments on China and the situation there?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: I guess I can just start with the quality questions since that's you're at specifically. Q4 tends to be a modest quarter for us quality-wise. We had about a dozen launches, but the dynamic that we have there is that we tried to freeze the launches after Thanksgiving so that we have stability for our advertisers around the holiday period. So from an overall impact on RPM perspective, the quality launches are actually more modest, some of the ads changes that we made, site links, comparison ads and product extensions certainly started to take effect as did the fact that all our advertisers are now on Ad Boards Three [ph], which we think is allowing them to be much more effective in terms of their bidding efforts. But I would generally describe the quarter as relatively modest from a quality perspective. Nikesh and others maybe can give you their perspective on Mobile. The main thing that I think we're starting to see there is that advertisers are getting better at figuring out what kind of ads work on the mobile devices. The simple addition, for example, if things like, including a phone number or an offer is substantially increasing the click-through rates and the ROI for the subset of advertisers who are correctly optimizing their mobile campaign. So we're certainly seeing very strong growth there.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Just a close on mobile, there really is a too -- if you think about it, too strong strategy on it, which is one is driving innovation in the ecosystem on one side. So when you think of all of the applications like Goggles, and all of the -- we would have seen on voice-recognition and navigation. That's all innovation that basically drives people to the Web with these new mobile applications. Obviously, the more people spend their time on it, then they trigger into search and then monetization occurs. So for that perspective, I think that's the core engine of the mobile model. On China, I suggest that Eric answers that one please.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Ben, I think the China stuff has been covered really quite well in the press. Just a review for everybody on the call, we announced about more than a week ago, three reasonably separate facts. One, that there had been a cyber attack on Google, probably emanating from China, origin, details unknown, still under investigation. We believe we've made the necessary technical changes to prevent such a future attack. The second was a -- we discovered in the course of that, a perhaps related, perhaps unrelated, monitoring of human rights activists, which we disclosed, in the spirit that people will be aware that this may be occurring. And then third, was a decision for those reasons and other reasons, a decision for Google to no longer be willing to apply the censorship rules in China. This has a bunch of consequences, one of course is that we're in conversation with the Chinese government. The second is that our business in China is today unchanged. We continue to follow their laws. We continue to offer censored results. But at a reasonably short time from now, we will be making some changes there. We've made a strong statement that we wish to remain in China. We like the Chinese people. We like our Chinese employees. We like the business opportunities there. And we'd like to do that on somewhat different terms than we have. But we'll remain quite committed to being there. So I hope that helps.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Justin Post from Merrill Lynch.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: My question is more on competitive issues and Search, looks like U.S. did accelerated while expecting to have the biggest impact, but are you seeing any share changes internationally related to any of your competitive initiatives? And secondly, on the partner environment, are you seeing more competitive pressure on signing up partners, given some of the initiatives of your competitors out there?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: On the competition question, I think it's better for us to focus on what we do and not what our competitors are doing. I think our results are to speak for themselves. And I'll let you judge how they're doing and the market, but it's a highly competitive market. The one area where there's going to be a pretty big competitive event is whatever happens in China, which at this point is obviously unknown, but that would clearly, clearly make a difference.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: We continue to work closely with our pack of partners both on the Search and the Display side. And most of our partnerships are based on very clear ROI and very clear benefits to partners and to us. And we haven't seen any change from our partner experiences in Q3 into Q4.  In fact on the content side, right? The announcement of TiVo, the announcement of Channel 4, Channel 5 and U.K. for YouTube, there's in fact have been an increase. And we're very pleased about these type of partnerships.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Doug Anmuth from Barclays Capital.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could comment on the relative out performance of the Network business versus LNO, if there's any particular dynamics, then that would make network growth higher? And then secondly, can you also comment on the higher marketing costs that you saw during the quarter, and in particular, how much of that is attributable to Android launches, and the Droid in particular?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: In terms of O&O versus network, nothing really significant to disclose in this quarter. Our marketing, I think it's fair to say there's two things. There's the high level and then I'll let Nikesh give a couple of comments. At the higher level, remember when we said at the end of Q3that we wanted to ramp up our investments in a bunch of areas to accelerate our growth? Marketing is one that you can actually affect in the short term quite well. And because we have such a kind of scientific approach to track it, we decided to invest a bit more in Q4. So Nikesh could probably give you a couple of examples to that.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Yes, for example many of our marketing efforts in Q4 have been targeted towards trying to educate and bring more and more small advertisers into the Web where you can clearly measure the ROI and clearly  understand what the impact of those is. So that's been one big focus. We have to be focused on the consumer side, has just been to support some of our more consumer launches that should happen in Q4.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Imran Khan from JPMorgan.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: You talked about Search traffic increased to five times on mobile. If I understand that unit economics what kind of revenue per Search on mobile you are seeing compared to the PC? And secondly, couple of questions, more related questions on the cost side, you talked about that spend more on the marketing in Q4, is it more of a one-time nature? Do you expect that to go down in Q1? And also, how much were bonus accruals for Q4 due to exceeding your full-year trend? And how should we think the bonus cycle [ph] will go down in Q1?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Let me start with bonus, then we'll go back to the other question of marketing. So on bonus, here's what everybody has to remember because last year, you'll remember there's a lot of questions about that. When we start a year, we reset the plan, and as we progress through the year, if we had varied to plan, whether positive or negative, then we have to make additional accruals, but at the beginning we just don't know that. So in 2010, next quarter, you can expect that we will reset our plan and therefore, we'll go back to the base number. For this year, 2009, specifically, we had actually by Q3 figured out that we had a different trajectory than the base line, and what we did is in consequence, is actually we did a combination of cash up to Q3 and Q4 to make sure that we were properly provisioned for the bonus at year end. And that's why you haven't seen like at the end of Q4 of last year, a big lift for that reason. We've increased but just in proportion to the second half of the year. So that's the key on bonus. On marketing, I think the issue from a financial perspective, clearly, we don't get any perspective view on marketing. I think the most important thing is that, we're really pleased with the experiments we're running right now in the marketing domain. And again I'll circle back to Nikesh if he wants to give more precision on it.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: I'm just going to echo what Patrick said. We are going to look at the campaigns that we have in place. We're going to looking at our products that we have in place. And based on the ROI of those campaigns, we're going to ratchet our spend up for now in the following quarters.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And on Mobile, maybe Jonathan?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: I'm not going to give specifics on Mobile RPMs versus desktop RPMs, but I think the main thing we can say is that the new formats, the targeting tools and the reporting that we're giving, the mobile advertisers is making the huge difference. And I mentioned Click-to-Call, putting phone numbers in the mobile ads making a difference. Try something  like auto insurance on your phone, and you'll see that the progress of that on the phone actually shows the phone number while on the PC it doesn't. Nikesh gave the Razorfish example in his opening remarks, and we're also letting the advertisers target high-end devices, specific devices or specific carriers. And we've also launched the reporting with Analytics to the mobile phones. So we're starting to see much improved monetization in general across Mobile.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Brian Pitz from UBS.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Over the past couple of quarters, you've rolled out  several new ad formats such as site links and video ads on the google.com site, could you discuss the adoption of these formats among advertisers? And; any commentary on if these formats have potentially lowered paid clicks and increased CPCs on the site?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: So have the ad formats we launched in Q4 had been very successful, the advertisers have taken them up very effectively. We've actually used our direct sales force across the U.S, as well as across major parts of Europe and work with some of our larger advertisers to introduce cyclings to the larger ad formats. I'll pass the CPC question back to Patrick.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: I mean we won't comment on the very specifics of each one of them. But it's very clear that when you have product listing ads that have comment, either new cost per action pricing model, as that includes images and pricing within them, or even the comparison ads that we've now kind of started introducing. I mean, all these obviously, provide more information to the user and therefore more value. So from that perspective, it's been a real positive.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: For people that are confused, the easiest way to see what we're talking about is just try typing something like Sears into Google and you'll see the example of what Nikesh was referring to as cyclings. And it's intuitively easy to see how they lead to higher user engagement. You'll see the Electronics in Tools sections, the deal of the day and you can see how much of a better experience that is, both for the advertiser and for the user.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Spencer Wang from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: So my question is regarding YouTube monetization. I know you guys have talked about being happy with the monetization at YouTube. I was wondering if you could just give us, perhaps, some updated metrics on how much of YouTube has been monetized? I think in previous calls, you've said it's tripled year over year. So any update on that would be great.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: For once we're not going to give any specific metrics on YouTube. What I can say is the big shift we are continuing to see in Youtube is that it's gone from being a nice-to-have to an essential part of the media mix of any display campaign that our advertisers are planning. And that's a big shift from our perspective and we continue to see people. And if you look at YouTube, it's very easy to see. You will see that our homepage ads are there on there, our watch page ads are there on there. And we have been able to expand that across the world in many markets where we have YouTube in place.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: You had paid performance on -- I mean, just to close on, just when people think of, kind of key insights on YouTube, right? The homepage was nearly sold out in Q4 and that was a great testimony of the power of YouTube and we're not running ads in 20 countries world wide. So again to give a sense of perspective of how successful the YouTube has been. So I hope that's useful, Spencer.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Scott Devitt from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: There was date in the quarter that suggested that large branded retailers grew online sales at roughly 15% in the quarter, and that smaller retailers experienced slower growth. And given your broad visibility into ad spending in particularly the long tail in smaller advertisers, I wonder if you could just comment on ad spending trends by advertiser size?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: As I alluded to this earlier, our larger advertisers continue to increase in online spending and operating search and online display within marketing mix. So the retail has been particularly strong during the holiday season. Most of the large retailers have created very robust websites, and they're able to target a very, very large host of keywords, and just to some degree, automated to stop. And we continue to work with some of our smaller advertisers and bring them to frey [ph]. It's purely a mix issue and a seasonal issue where we've seen the larger advertisers outperform the smaller ones.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Sandeep Aggarwal from Collins Stewart.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Can you please rank your non-core search businesses in terms of the growth potential i.e. Display, YouTube, Mobiline abs [ph] and then also any color you can add on your partnership/competitor dynamics with Google and Apple?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: It depends on whether you're looking at absolute growth or percentage growth. Obviously, the smaller ones are going to grow faster than the larger ones. We have said for a pretty long time that the next huge business for us is Display. And we put in place a series of acquisitions, a series of products. We've integrated them. We're seeing the benefit of -- I think one of the stories that's not really come out yet is how successful Google is at Display. I think you will see that especially in 2010. So if I were to talk about absolute numbers that are not Search, I would say that's probably your number one. But obviously, the smaller ones will grow faster on a relative basis. They are the most obvious one. In terms of growth rate, it would be Mobile. And a lot of that depends on the competitive dynamics of the industry, how successful the new AFMA [ph] product from us is. The AFMA ad[ph] acquisition if that comes through. We have a lot of evidence that people are moving to these data-friendly mobile devices very, very quickly. Our Search traffic is quite a -- Growth rate is quite a bit faster than our PCs. We expect that to continue. So for lots of reasons, 2010 will be a year of significant mobile revenue growth for the whole industry and I'm sure Google will play a major part of that. With respect to Apple, it's probably better to say that Apple, I, as a former board member, have a special spot for Apple in my heart. But I will tell you that Apple is a very well-run company. They've got a lot of very good stuff coming. We have a couple of very good partnerships with them. And it's clear we also compete with them in a couple of areas. And my guess is that's a pretty stable situation for a while.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext:
.
And we'll take our next question from Jeetil Patel from Deutsche Bank Securities.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: You got a $23 billion business built around advertising and that seems like it's got some sensitivities at the macro environment these days. I guess broadly, as you look forward into broader ecosystem of consumers and business partners you work with, are there newer, more unique ways that's kind of adding value to the broader ecosystem in terms of new revenue models or business models that are kind of maybe worthwhile exploring as you look ahead. And to try to break away from the sensitivity of ad business, that seems to be tied to macro. Second on Mobile, your strategy seems to be a little bit perplexing in that. You've got a partnership strategy with a slew of handset OEMs. And then the Nexus One, I guess is that a comparison of network and, oh no, is that kind of how we should think about the evolve -- the kind of evolution of that strategy, or you're just trying to push the smartphone category, and be the, obviously, the interface and the brand that consumers use to access information through those devices

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: On your question at the macro, we said last year and reiterate, that we are not immune to global economic trends. I think the evidence would say that we faired better than most companies in a global economic downturn. And hopefully, global recovery is clearly underway at this point. We've seen that at least for six months or maybe longer. So I'm not so worried about our reliance on ads, which is the sort of the premise of your question. From our perspective, our goal, as a business, is to solve the advertisers' and the other search businesses' problems, which is ultimately about selling product and marketing them and so forth. We are in various conversations about trying to do alternative ways to distribute this traditional content. We're trying to come up with new ways of using GPS data to sort of advertise against position in place. We have a lot of initiatives in this category. The ones that we'll probably have the biggest impact are not in that, as much as those are exciting, will probably be in the Display area. Because in the aggregate's side, our Display business will give people an opportunity to reach people with visual stories, with images, with narratives, but they couldn't do a search text. So it's probably the case that the combination of local advertising, all the things that we're doing on the Display, plus some of these new and more speculative things will likely to drive a lot of new ways of solving the businesses' problems. We haven't talked very much about this. We have quite a healthy enterprise business that's going to grow, we think quite rapidly within the next few years, as people move from the older legacy sort of PC-centric traditional operating system model to the new web-based application model. And the trend there is clear. Everyone is moving there. We're going to be one of the leaders there.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Eric, you want to comment on the issue of mobile and the question that was about the perplexity of our business model?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: The second part of your question, of course, was on Nexus One, in that model. And there isn't a lot of confusion about that. It's probably easiest to understand on the following way. What the Nexus One is really about is a new way of buying a phone. And the Nexus One is simply the first of a series of examples where you can essentially purchase a phone online from one or multiple manufacturers, self provision it or have it just work. And we think that's a natural evolution of a particular model. It does not exclude the other models, I think it's comparable with them in the sense that the retail model will continue to be quite successful. So, so far, our partners have understood that message and they have been okay with it and the Nexus One, itself, of course, is just a magnificent product.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Jason Helfstein from Oppenheimer and Co.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Are you seeing -- do you think Bing is having an impact on cost-per-click? And then number two, do you expect the tax rate to rise in 2010 with the improvement in U.S. revenues?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Let me answer the second one first and then we can come back to the first one. But on the issue of taxation, obviously, we don't give any kind of guidance forward. We continue to monitor very closely all the issues related to those tax bills and the legislation. And obviously, where like most American companies that have large international presence, we continue to believe that it would be kind of a disadvantage to have some of the proposals that had been tabled. So we're going to continue participating in the process very actively to make our voice heard but we can't speculate as to the outcomes of these things. In terms of Bing, Jonathan, you want to give a comment on it?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: We generally don't comment on competitors. We think our CPCs are not generally impacted by what other search engines do. Our CPCs are set by competition among advertisers and we've got a very competitive auction market.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: That's the essence of the point, right? I mean, people choose. So why don't we go to the next question please.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Gene Munster from Piper Jaffray.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: You guys talk a little bit about the impact of Nexus One to the models, specifically, the margins going forward?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: In its most simplistic form, we don't track percentage margins as part of our business model. What we're looking for is opportunities to innovate, to ship product that we think really are kind of disruptive game changing into the benefit of users. And the Nexus One is a great example of that in setting the bar as to what a great Mobile headset should look like. And it will have its own margin, and that's how we're focused on building the business.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext:
.
And we'll take our next question from Mark May from Needham & Company.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: We've been hearing from a number of AdSense partners like Google's TAC rate is trending toward Google's favor. Is the fourth quarter TAC decline a reflection of a declining trend in TAC or is it just seasonal? And then the second question is, I think investors have a good sense of the assets in such the Google brings to bear in the online Display space but doesn't have a good sense of the size of Google's Display business and the trend in market share there. So the question is just how big in fact does Google in Display today?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Let me start with the TAC issues, we have a lot of great partnerships with so many of our AdSense partners and other partners. The fact that it's been trending down has to do simply with kind of mix issues, and it's not really tied to seasonality. So there's nothing of a big surprise there in our mind and we continue to have great partnerships with all of our partners on AdSense and others. In the case of Display, I think that the few facts that we shared already on the last webcast on Display that are worth mentioning is the industry itself is a  $17 billion industry. So it's a big pie and if you just take the TV advertising industry, which is a $170 billion industry, that is all I buy [ph] instead of shifting over time to the Internet or the digital content. That's also going to make its -- some of it's going to make it's way progressively to Display. So there's no doubt that it's a huge pie to go after. And then from our side, we clearly don't comment on the specifics of our market share or our revenue dollars, but I think you should take from the tonality of Eric's comments that this is really a big focus for us because it's got a lot of runway. And I'll leave it at that, if you don't mind.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Youssef Squali from Jefferies & Company.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: First on Mobile, we've seen from some third-party data that the iPhone may account for almost as much as 50% of overall. Mobile traffic first, is that kind of similar to what you're hearing or what you've seen? And I guess related to that, Eric, you said earlier or you mentioned that you see the Apple relationship as stable. Are you inferring from that, that you think the upcoming renegotiations of that deal and potential of it moving to a competitor likely to moving your favor? And on the Display side, can you give us a sense of the percentage of Search advertisers that are buying Display from you today? And what is the major pushback from this that don't?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: We're not going to speculate on the market share of Apple Mobile products. That's for Apple to discuss with you. And as far as I could tell, our business structures with Apple are quite stable. I'm not going to speculate on any deals of any kind, rumored true, not true, you name it, we're not going to talk about it. On the Display question?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: On the Display side, there's a reasonable number of our Search advertisers who also buy in Display. It actually depends on their campaign objectives. If their campaign objectives are sort of response-oriented, they favor search, as well as certain parts of the Display network, which would give them a higher conversion rate and a higher clicked rate as it relates to the advertising. If they're more brand focused, they tend to over weight Display in their campaign and that category, clearly, they have many choices, including YouTube, as far as where they spend their premium brand dollars.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext:
.
And we'll go next to Marianne Wolk with Susquehanna Financial Group.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: Given how attractive you're making the new Display products to advertisers and the big push with your sales force, have you seen any of your advertisers shift budget from Search into the newer Display offering? And then as a follow-up, how do we think about what's going on at the content network? Where are you in transforming that from basically contextual advertising to Display?

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: On the question of shifting, my experience with advertisers, they don't shift the ad. And the reason is that, that the systems that they make are sort of stand-alone. In other words, they will simply maximize the amount of Search advertising they do to maximize their revenue. And then the Display decision is the decision that they make, which is both a revenue and also strategic decision around their branding and so forth. And that's growing as we can offer, if you will, the science of Google applied to the Display business. And that's our differentiator, we do it better than anybody else. And that's why we continue to win all those deals.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: We're going to close on this for now. I want to thank everyone for taking your time to listen to our call today. As you can tell, we're very excited about moving the business forward in 2010. I want to take a moment to thank also all of the Googlers that have been listening to this call for their hard work. 2009 was a roller-coaster year, very strong performance and really the achievement of everybody on the team. So on behalf of the management team, thank you to all.  And thank you for listening and Jonathan and I will talk to you in half an hour. Cheers.

headline: Google Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan-21-2010
componenttext: And this concludes today's conference. We thank you for your participation. Youtube
